items: Rectal bleeding - gross or occult.
Polyps or carcinoma - suspected or known.
Inflammatory bowel disease - suspected or known.
Patient over 40 years of age who can cooperate and turn over without assistance.
Suspected acute perforation.
Acute, fulminating colitis.
Immediately after biopsy.

blocks.text: Patient preparation: see appendix by the same name.

items: Barium sulfate suspension (either of the following):
Liquid Polibar Plus (E-Z-EM., Inc., Westbury, N. Y.) - supplied premixed at 105% W/V.
Medebar Plus (Lafayette Pharmaceuticals, Lafayette, IN) - supplied premixed at 100% W/V.
1000 ml enema bag with large bore (1/2") tubing attached to a Miller Air enema tip with nonlatex retention cuff (balloon), blue insufflator bulb, white balloon insufflator pouch, and Kelly clamp.
Lead glove.
Compression paddle with balloon.

Glucagon (Eli Lilly, Indianapolis, IN) - 1 mg, 1 cc syringe, alcohol prep, and tourniquet. At any time there is spasm in the large bowel or if the patient becomes extremely uncomfortable, administer 1 mg of glucagon slowly I.V. over one minute (to decrease nausea/vomiting). Some radiologists prefer prophylactic I.V. glucagon in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (spastic colon) or severe diverticulosis.
Evaluate preliminary plain radiograph of the abdomen for relative contraindications (retained stool or contrast material in the colon).
Evaluate for absolute contraindications to performing a barium enema (free air, rigid abdomen).
Question the patient about relevant symptoms and previous abdominal surgery.
Question the patient about the "three P's" (pregnancy, recent procto, and bowel prep).
Explain the procedure to the patient. Ask if they have questions. Talk to the patient throughout the examination to decrease anxiety and divert attention.

An aide/technologist shakes the barium to a uniform suspension, pours 350 ml into the enema bag, runs barium through the tubing to expel air, and clamps the tubing. The assistant places the patient on the left side, lubricates the enema tip, and inserts it into the rectum. If difficulty occurs, the radiologist performs a digital rectal exam and inserts the tip.

blocks.text: Modification of the "7 Pump Method" developed by Drs. Roscoe Miller and Dean Maglinte.

items: The patient remains in the left lateral position.
Unclamp the tubing and allow barium to flow by gravity or by gently squeezing the enema bag.

When you estimate that the rectum is filled with barium, check the position of the enema tip with fluoroscopy and inflate the retention balloon in the rectal ampulla with only one puff of air during fluoroscopic monitoring.
Avoid rectal discomfort and urgency by only half-filling the balloon.
The purpose of the balloon is to keep the enema tip from coming out, not to block egress of barium.
Note: Do not inflate the retention balloon in the presence of a large rectal tumor, acute inflammation, stricture, or recent biopsy because of the potential for rectal perforation.
Note: No further fluoroscopy is ordinarily necessary until Step 4.
As the barium continues to flow, tilt the head of the x-ray table down about 15. When the bag is empty, clamp the tubing and return the table to a horizontal position.

Begin insufflating air at no more than one puff per second. Add 5 puffs of air in each of the following 9 patient positions: left lateral, LAO, prone, RAO, right lateral, RPO, supine, left lateral, and finally prone.

After the final turn and air insufflation, verify that barium has entered the ascending colon. If barium is in the ascending colon, proceed to Step 5. If not, perform Modification #1, followed by Modification #2 if needed.
With the patient prone, raise the head of the table to 45. Place the barium bag between the patient?s legs, unclamp the tubing, and allow barium to drain from the rectosigmoid.
Return the table to horizontal. Turn the patient supine.
During fluoroscopic monitoring, instill enough air to distend the rectosigmoid.
Take RPO and LPO spot images of the sigmoid colon.
Roll the patient onto the left side.

Raise the head of the table to 75. With the colon distended, some patients have a vaso-vagal reaction when standing. Advise the patient to warn you if they feel faint so you can lower the table before syncope.
With the patient upright, unclamp the tubing and allow barium to drain into the enema bag while taking spot images of the hepatic and splenic flexures.
Rotate the patient back into LPO position. Take spot image of hepatic flexure.
Rotate the patient into RPO position. Take spot image of splenic flexure.
Clamp the enema bag tubing.
Lower the table to horizontal.
Roll the patient into the left lateral position.
Lower the head of the table down to -10.
Roll the patient supine or RPO. Take a spot image of the cecum with graded compression.
Turn the patient prone.
Raise the head of the x-ray table to +45.
Put the enema bag between the patient?s legs and, for a third time, drain barium from the rectosigmoid.
Return the table to horizontal.
Add air slowly until the entire colon is well filled (let transverse colon distension be your guide).
Then, have the technologist take overhead radiographs.

Modification #1: If barium has not reached the ascending colon after Step 4, turn the patient 360 degrees in each direction. When prone again, reassess. If barium is in the ascending colon, proceed to Step 5. If not, go to Modification #2. Do not insufflate additional air at this point to avoid an air-lock in the cecum.

Modification #2: After failed Modification #1, pour one liter of thin (dilute) barium into the enema bag. Use thin barium as a plunger to push thicker double-contrast barium into the ascending colon. After the head of the column reaches the ascending colon, return to Step 5 and proceed as usual.
PA view of colon to include rectum - perpendicular central ray - 14" x 17" cassette.
15 RAO view of rectosigmoid with 35 caudad central ray - 14" x 17" cassette.
RPO view of colon to include splenic flexure and descending colon - 14" x 17" cassette.
LPO view of colon to include hepatic flexure and ascending colon - 14" x 17" cassette.
LPO view of rectosigmoid with 35 cephalad central ray on 14" x 17" cassette.
Right lateral decubitus view of colon to include rectum on 14" x 17" cassette (after #6, turn patient through prone position to obtain #7).
Left lateral decubitus view of colon to include rectum on 14" x 17" cassette (before this film, deflate rectal balloon, add two pumps of air to rectum, and remove enema tip).
Lateral rectum with horizontal beam (cross-table) with patient prone on 10" x 12" cassette.
